key_residues.description: Experimentally verified. Mutation E39A leads to loss of activity.
Experimentally verified. Mutation E70A leads to reduced activity.
Experimentally verified. Mutation H169A leads to complete loss of activity.
Experimentally verified. Mutation E39A leads to complete loss of activity, suggesting its role in coordinating metal ions within the catalytic site.
Experimentally verified. Mutation H133A causes complete loss of activity, indicating its involvement in the catalytic mechanism as part of the metal ion binding site.
Experimentally verified. Mutation D167A results in complete loss of activity, highlighting its crucial role in substrate binding and stabilization.
Experimentally verified. Mutation H169A leads to complete loss of activity, confirming its involvement in proton transfer during the catalytic process.
Experimentally verified. Mutation H191A results in loss of activity, supporting its role in coordinating the catalytic site as part of a metal-binding triad.
Experimentally verified. Mutation D332A leads to complete loss of activity, indicating its function as a key catalytic residue crucial for metal ion coordination.
Experimentally verified. Mutation F260A reduces the degradation rate of MC-LR, implying its role in substrate positioning rather than direct catalysis.
Experimentally verified. Mutation K464A results in a slower degradation rate, suggesting its involvement in maintaining the structural integrity of the active site.
Experimentally verified. Mutation E56A leads to complete loss of activity due to disruption of Zn²⁺ binding and failure to activate water molecule for nucleophilic attack.
Experimentally verified. Mutation H150A significantly reduces activity, indicating its crucial role in Zn²⁺ coordination.
Experimentally verified. Mutation D184A leads to complete loss of activity, likely due to destabilization of the Zn²⁺ binding environment.
Experimentally verified. Mutation H186A results in over 90% reduction in activity, highlighting its importance in Zn²⁺ coordination.
Experimentally verified. Mutation H208A causes approximately 85% reduction in activity, suggesting its critical role in maintaining the active site structure.
